title: Net Zero Carbon Rail
body: A railway that’s central to delivering a net zero economy by 2050

_items.right:
What does net zero actually mean?

Net zero means cutting greenhouse gas emissions to as close to zero as possible, with any remaining emissions re-absorbed from the atmosphere, by oceans and forests for instance.

So why does carbon matter?

Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the primary greenhouse gas emitted through human activities. Greenhouse gases act like a blanket wrapped around the earth, trapping the sun’s heat and raising temperatures high enough to cause climate change (long-term shifts in temperatures and weather patterns).

_items.leftAlt: Icon of a thermometer and the world
_items.right:
Why is climate change problematic?

Climate change causes extreme temperatures and severe storms, increased droughts and famine, rising ocean levels, loss of species, greater health risks, poverty and displacement.

title: How can rail make a difference?

_items.body: Depending on the scenario, travelling by rail emits 3-5 times fewer carbon emissions than driving, and about 6 times fewer than flying, per passenger km, while a single freight train may remove over 70 HGVs from the roads.
Encourage greater use of rail by passengers and commerce as part of a sustainable transport network.
Increase the installation and procurement of renewable electricity.
Implement energy efficiency measures or source renewable energy for the operation of buildings, road vehicles and supporting rail systems.
Collaborate with other sectors such as road, air and construction, to send a joint demand signal to manufacturers for low and zero-carbon materials.
Industry-wide management systems to consistently embed carbon reductions into decision making.

title: Seamless Journeys
body: Rail must fully integrate as part of a sustainable, joined-up transport system to support the shift of people and goods onto railways.
mobileInstruction: Select the next and back arrows to find out more.

_items.body: Rail needs to support a modal shift to rail, becoming the backbone of a cleaner, greener transport system for both passengers and freight.

title: How does rail noise affect the community?
displayTitle: How does rail noise affect the community?
instruction: Choose one or more options and select Submit.

_items.text: Rail noise adversely affects the health and quality of life of significant numbers of people.
Noise and vibration can have a negative impact on local businesses, social infrastructure, heritage assets and biodiversity.
There are regular complaints about noise and vibration around depots, stations, at level crossings, and alongside the railways.
Working on the railway is made easier by the multitude of noise sources.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
That’s right.

Noise, defined as unwanted sound, affects rail’s customers, neighbours and colleagues. Vibration can cause harmful effects on people and damage infrastructure, such as buildings.

Evidence shows that noise adversely affects health and quality of life, excessive noise can have detrimental effects on mental health. Noise and vibration can also have a negative impact on local businesses, social infrastructure, heritage assets and biodiversity.

There are regular complaints about noise and vibration around depots, stations, at level crossings, and alongside the railways. These most often relate to diesel trains idling and moving within depots, particularly at night and early in the morning, as well as train horns and PA announcements.

Working on the railway can be physically and mentally demanding; the multitude of noise sources can add to these demands.

title: A railway for nature
instruction: Select an option for each statement and select Submit.

_items.text: Choose the best definition for Biodiversity Net Gain (BNG).

_options.text: Biodiversity net gain delivers measurable improvements for biodiversity by removing buildings and other structures in order to re-wild the land.
Biodiversity net gain delivers measurable improvements for biodiversity by creating or enhancing habitats in association with development.

_items.text: What has the government said about rail and BNG?

_options.text: Rail is not taking its responsibilities regarding BNG seriously.
Rail has a huge amount to offer in terms of contributing to biodiversity net gain (BNG), helping the natural environment recover, and connecting people with nature.

_items.text: Which of these actions will help rail to support BNG?

_options.text: Providing recycling facilities and using clear, consistent signs that promote sustainable decisions.
Developing a full biodiversity baseline, with habitat map and associated Biodiversity Action Plan.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
That’s right.

Net Biodiversity Gain is a strategy to develop land and contribute to the recovery of nature. It is a way of making sure the habitat for wildlife is in a better state than it was before development.

A 2018 independent review of Network Rail’s approach to vegetation management in England and Wales states that the Government believes rail has a huge amount to offer in terms of contributing to biodiversity net gain (BNG), helping the natural environment recover, and connecting people with nature.

As one of the country’s largest public landowners, Network Rail is developing a full biodiversity baseline, with habitat map and associated Biodiversity Action Plan, with progress to be reported annually.
